intro: Brassica acris, commonly known as field mustard, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm and features basal leaves that are pinnately lobed. The plant produces yellow flowers in racemes, which are followed by long, slender pods containing seeds. It thrives in disturbed soils and is often found in fields, roadsides, and waste areas. Brassica acris is a member of the Brassicaceae family, known for its characteristic cruciform flowers and mustard oils.
